wiki.text:
'Forecasting' is the process of making statements about events whose actual
outcomes (typically) have not yet been observed. A commonplace example might be
estimation of some variable of interest at some specified future date.
Prediction is a similar, but more general term. Both might refer to formal
statistical methods employing time series, cross-sectional or longitudinal data,
or alternatively to less formal judgemental methods. Usage can differ between
areas of application: for example, in hydrology, the terms "forecast" and
"forecasting" are sometimes reserved for estimates of values at certain specific
future times, while the term "prediction" is used for more general estimates,
such as the number of times floods will occur over a long period.

Risk and uncertainty are central to forecasting and prediction; it is generally
considered good practice to indicate the degree of uncertainty attaching to
forecasts. In any case, the data must be up to date in order for the forecast to
be as accurate as possible.<ref></ref> <!-- old FAQ version here:
http://qbox.wharton.upenn.edu/documents/mktg/research/FAQ.pdf -->
